awd_titl_txt: CAREER:   Investigating environmental acidification and temperature as drivers of morphological alteration and physiological deficits in auditory systems of soniferous fishes
awd_abstract_narration:
Since the Industrial Revolution, the ocean has become 30% more acidic due to its uptake of carbon dioxide, and coastal areas and freshwaters are frequently more acidic still due to inputs from natural and agricultural land and human activities in adjacent watersheds.  The goal of this CAREER project is to examine the effects of temperature and carbon dioxide exposure on the structure and function of the auditory (hearing) systems of closely-related sound-producing fishes of the croaker/drum family Sciaenidae.  These fishes are model organisms for the study of fish hearing and communication, most support valuable recreational fisheries in habitats ranging from fresh through salt water, and nearly all produce sounds to aid in reproduction and/or to raise alarm when disturbed or threatened. While auditory sense is of great importance to these sound producing fishes, little is known about the effects of changing environmental conditions on fish hearing and communication.  This project's interdisciplinary approach will make significant impacts in this rapidly emerging field that will be of broad interest to both the ocean science and recreational fishing stakeholder communities. The award supports recruitment and professional development of postdoctoral, graduate, and undergraduate researchers from underrepresented groups in STEM disciplines. Student training includes mastery of quantitative reasoning, critical thinking, and communication skills regarding environmental impacts on aquatic ecosystems and sustainable stewardship of future ecosystems. 

This CAREER Award will expand the interdisciplinary neurosensory laboratory developed at Hampton University under the PI's earlier Research Initiation Award to examine how changing environmental conditions over the next century may affect the form and function of auditory systems of phylogenetically-related soniferous fishes that rely on auditory communication during aggregate spawning. This project will apply electrophysiological techniques and morphological analyses to assay the effects of increased temperature and CO2 concentrations representative of projected changes over the next century on auditory morphology and neurosensory function in representative freshwater, estuarine, and fully marine sciaenid fishes. Using related fishes from a common phylogeny but differing habitats and life histories, this project will examine the effects of chronic aqueous CO2 exposure (i.e. acidification) and increased temperature on the: (1) morphological development of sensory structures via digital microscopy and computerized tomography (CT), (2) neurosensory performance of auditory systems via Auditory Brainstem Response, and (3) manipulation of the GABA neurotransmitter to alter sensory deficits during CO2 exposure. This CAREER project will enhance research capacity and provide critical infrastructure that will support continued research by the PI, a postdoctoral associate, and both graduate and undergraduate students from underrepresented backgrounds in STEM beyond the award's lifetime.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
PROJECT OVERVIEW:  Recent high-impact studies suggest that atmospheric CO2 levels projected over the next century will result in levels of aquatic acidification that cause physical and behavioral changes in aquatic organisms, linking environmental changes to changes in morphology. However, the extent to which the physiological function of fish neurosensory systems is altered as a consequence of environmental acidification, and the functional deficits it may cause, have been chronically understudied. In marine waters, CO2 concentrations risen by 30% since the Industrial resolution (a magnitude of ~ 0.25 to 0.5 pH unit change over 1-2 centuries), but daily CO2 swings can be far more extreme in coastal and estuarine waters (on the order to 05 to 1 pH unit on a single tidal cycle). Does their differential environmental experience render coastal fishes more resilient to pH changes than marine fishes? 

Intellectual Merit.  Research activities conducted under this CAREER Award to an Historically Black College/University (HBCU) therefore applied electrophysiological techniques and morphological analyses to assay the effects of increased temperature and CO2 concentrations representative of projected changes over the next century on the form and function of auditory (hearing) systems in species of sound-producing fishes from the croaker/drum family Sciaenidae: estuarine spot (Leiostomus xanthurus) and fully marine, reef-associated high hat drum (Pareques acuminatus). Using related fishes from a common phylogeny but differing habitats and life histories, this project examined the effects of three levels of CO2 exposure (i.e. acidification) and two temperatures on the: (1) morphological development of sensory structures, notably the sagittal otoliths (ear stones) of fishes, (2) neurosensory performance of auditory systems, and (3) manipulation of the GABA-A neurotransmitter to alter sensory deficits during CO2 exposure. Briefly, spot auditory function and otolith morphology were unaffected by CO2 exposure, but the former was significantly impaired by exposure to high temperatures (30C).  In other words, spot at lower temperatures were able to hear fainter sounds that spot at high temperatures could not.  This suggests that estuarine and near-coastal fishes may be resilient to acidification, and face greater sensory challenges from rising temperatures than from changing coastal and oceanic pH levels.  In contrast, fully marine high hat drum experienced significant auditory deficits and slight shape anomalies in auditory organs after high CO2 exposures, but no loss of function or change in morphology due to high temperature challenges.  This suggests that acidification may be a greater sensory stressor for fully marine subtropical and tropical fishes than temperature. Collectively, this research shows that acidification and thermal impacts are not constant across phylogeny, but rather can affect related species differently.  As such, ambient environmental conditions (or their typically variability) in native environments/habitats may be a better predictor for species resilience to CO2 and temperature challenges than phylogeny. Finally, this research demonstrates that auditory function can be disrupted by acidification and temperature challenges in the absence of significant changes to auditory morphological structures, likely due to higher order neurological processes.

Broader Impacts. During its lifetime, this CAREER Award focused on the recruitment, retention, and professional development of underrepresented researchers at a Minority Serving Institution(MSI)/HBCU. The project trained one underrepresented PDA and three undergraduates from underrepresented backgrounds in the geosciences. Significant emphasis was placed on written and oral communication skills via the development of a student capstone thesis, five conference presentations at national and international geoscience societies, the publication of results in four articles in peer-reviewed journals of high impact, one peer reviewed book chapter, and four additional manuscripts in varied stages of development.  The project additionally generated a successful tenure outcome for the PI, and professional development and experience sufficient for a successful outcome for a highly competitive position to lead ocean acidification research activities at a federal facility. This CAREER award was prematurely ended in 2022 and the remainder of funds returned when the PI left his tenured academic position for a federal research career that enabled further study of ocean acidification impacts on the physiology of marine organisms; the postdoctoral associate (PDA) also accepted a career position with a natural resource management federal agency.
